author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: New Image Shows Suspect in C.E.O. Shooting in Back of Taxi
description: The manhunt for the gunman who fatally shot Brian Thompson, chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, entered its fifth day, and the police released two new images.
content: The New York Police Department has released two new images of the man it believes fatally shot the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, including one showing him in the back seat of a taxi on the day of the shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Adam Entous
title: Biden Weighs Approach to Rebels in Syria Amid Secret Message Exchange
description: President Biden faces the challenge of deciding how to engage the main armed group that toppled President Bashar al-Assad, even though it remains designated a terrorist organization by the United States.
content: For President Biden, the fall of Syria’s tyrant on Sunday was a moment to cheer what he called a “fundamental act of justice” and to claim a measure of credit for his own policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: She Sued Over Transgender ‘Conversion Therapy,’ a First for China
description: Ling’er won a settlement payout from the hospital where she was held for three months against her will and subjected to electroshock therapy.
content: For years after coming out as transgender, Ling’er, an aspiring influencer in eastern China, struggled from heartbreak to heartbreak. Her family refused to accept her. When she tried to find an interim job to support herself, employers would not hire her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Ana Swanson
title: Commerce Dept. Is on the Front Lines of China Policy
description: The department has confronted the challenge of China by restricting key exports, a policy that is likely to continue in the Trump administration.
content: The Commerce Department has traditionally focused on promoting the interests of American business and increasing U.S. exports abroad. But in recent years, it has taken on a national security role, working to defend the country by restricting exports of America’s most powerful computer chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: They Love France. So When Notre-Dame Burned, They Wanted to Help.
description: A couple from North Carolina are part of the second-largest group of donors to the huge fund-raising effort to restore the famous cathedral: Americans.
content: Like many of the millions of tourists who visit Paris, Nick and Suzie Trivisonno, of Charlotte, N.C., would usually catch at least a glimpse of Notre-Dame on their frequent visits to town. Often, the Trivisonnos, who are Catholics, would go to the cathedral and pray — for family, friends and peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arnab Datta
title: Climate Activists Need to Radically Change Their Approach Under Trump
description: Climate purity is a recipe for failure.
content: Donald Trump’s return to Washington might seem like a terrifying moment for the fight against climate change. The incoming administration is not just hostile to the energy transition; it’s also expected to pull the United States out of the Paris climate agreement, roll back a wide range of pollution regulations and promote domestic fossil fuel production — decisions likely to worsen global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Tom Jamieson For The New York Times
title: Inside the Four-Day Workweek Experiment
description: A British group is pushing for more companies to offer their workers shorter hours. Here’s what it looks like for two companies willing to test it out.
content: On a recent Wednesday morning, Matt Kimber did not sign into his job as a senior engineer at a software company. Instead, he went for a walk around his London neighborhood, picked up lunch at a cafe, and played with his two greyhounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: How I Aged Into the Bad Christmas Movie
description: One December morning, a millennial critic awoke to discover that she had been begrudgingly charmed by an onslaught of Hallmark and Netflix holiday films.
content: When I first discovered the existence of made-for-television Christmas movies, maybe 15 years ago, they struck me as sentimental and anti-feminist. Also, they seemed to be made for older people. The leads were always floundering in midlife until their romantic and professional lives were reformed through the magic of Christmas. Then, one December morning, I awoke to find that I had transformed into the target demographic. I am older now, and the movies are made just for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Threatened With Jail, Cheney Condemns Trump’s ‘Assault on the Rule of Law’
description: Liz Cheney, the former Republican representative, said President-elect Donald J. Trump “lied about” the bipartisan House committee that investigated his role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack.
content: Former Representative Liz Cheney on Sunday called President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threat to imprison her and other members of a congressional committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol an “assault on the rule of law and the foundations of our republic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Unidentified Drones Light Up New Jersey’s Skies, Baffling Residents
description: People across the state have reported seeing scores of large, low-flying objects in recent weeks. Officials haven’t said where they’re coming from, or why they’re here.
content: Brightly lit against a dark night sky, the low-flying object wasn’t a star, and it wasn’t moving like a plane or a helicopter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Morning Team
title: Assad’s Rule Ends
description: We explain the latest developments in Syria.
content: President Bashar al-Assad’s long and brutal reign in Syria has ended. After 13 years of civil war, Syria’s rebel fighters have stormed the capital, Damascus, and claimed victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Saikou Jammeh
title: A President Rejected by Voters Eight Years Ago Wins Election Again in Ghana
description: John Dramani Mahama, who served as president from 2012 to 2017, is set to return to office after his main opponent, Mahamudu Bawumia, conceded defeat.
content: John Dramani Mahama, a former president of Ghana who was voted out of office eight years ago, staged a dramatic political comeback on Sunday after his main opponent conceded defeat in the West African country’s presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Sarah Berman
title: For Taylor Swift, It’s the End of the ‘Eras’
description: A two-year tour that permeated the culture played one last night in the Canadian city of Vancouver.
content: Anyone with an ear tuned to the world of pop music knew the Eras Tour was going to be a big one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: S.N.L. Resurrects Church Lady: Isn’t That Special!
description: Playing his old familiar character, Dana Carvey talks about Jesus, tweaks celebrities for their sins and skewers Satan.
content: A quick primer for the younger readers of this recap: The late 1980s were a creatively fruitful time for “Saturday Night Live” where for some reason every third sketch was a fake talk show. Among the most popular of these recurring bits was a segment called “Church Chat,” in which a piously persnickety host known simply as the Church Lady (played by Dana Carvey) would roast celebrities of the day and accuse pretty much everyone of working in the service of Satan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Miho Nakayama, Japanese Music and Movie Star, Dies at 54
description: A top-selling pop singer as a teenager in the 1980s, she also had an award-winning career as a dramatic actress.
content: Miho Nakayama, a reigning J-pop star of the 1980s who broke through to become a critically acclaimed dramatic actress and gained international attention for her starring role in the sentimental Japanese drama “Love Letter,” died on Friday at her home in Tokyo. She was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: From Tarot Cards to Streamlined Design, We Can’t Stop Predicting the Future
description: In “A Century of Tomorrows,” Glenn Adamson offers a hurtling history of the art, science and big business of looking ahead.
content: God bless Donald Fagen for cursing out the “Yacht Rock” “dock”-umentarians. And God bless Fagen for writing the best song about the past’s vision of the future and how it all went sour: “I.G.Y. (What a Beautiful World),” named after the international geophysical year 1957-58, when scientists around the world collaborated on ambitious discovery projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Apple Sued for Failing to Curtail Child Sexual Abuse Material on iCloud
description: Victims of abuse are seeking more than $1.2 billion in damages, arguing that the company abandoned a 2021 system it developed to find abusive material.
content: The abuse began when she was still an infant. A relative molested her, took photographs and swapped the images with others online. He allowed another man to spend time with her, multiplying the abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: 43,000 Ukrainian Soldiers Killed Since Russia Invaded, Zelensky Says
description: The tally differs sharply from estimates by U.S. officials and military analysts, who have said the number is closer to 70,000.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Sunday that 43,000 Ukrainian soldiers had been killed and 370,000 wounded since Russia’s full-scale invasion began nearly three years ago. It was the first time in months that he had disclosed military casualty figures, a highly sensitive topic in Ukraine, particularly as Kyiv’s forces lose more ground to Russian troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Ouyang
title: What Doctors Like Myself Know About Americans’ Health Care Anger
description: As a doctor, I’ve been on both sides of frustrating health care debacles.
content: I rushed around the patient as he lay motionless with his eyes closed in the emergency room. He was pale and sweaty, his T-shirt stained with vomit. You didn’t have to be a health-care worker to know that he was in a dire state. The beeps on the monitor told me his heart rate was dangerously slow. I told the man that he was going to be admitted to the hospital overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Scrubbing Up for a Peek at the Resuscitated Notre-Dame Cathedral
description: Michael Kimmelman, the architecture critic for The New York Times, visited the Paris landmark last summer amid the restoration.
content: When Michael Kimmelman, the architecture critic for The New York Times, stepped inside the storied Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris last summer he was amazed. Awe-inspired, even. He was also in a head-to-toe white scrub suit, with rubber boots and a hard hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Raja Abdulrahim and Muhammad Haj Kadour
title: Syrians Mourn All They Have Lost, Even as They Celebrate
description: Thoughts of loved ones dead or missing complicate joyous relief at the prospect of Bashar al-Assad’s losing power.
content: For nearly all the years that the al-Assad family ruled Syria, silence reigned.  No one spoke freely, fearful of who might hear. Everyone knew the consequences of dissent: disappearance into government prisons, from which few ever returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: With Assad’s Fall, Iran’s ‘Axis of Resistance’ Unravels
description: Tehran’s main regional allies are weakened or collapsing: Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, has fled his country, Hezbollah is battered by conflict with Israel, and Hamas is still at war.
content: Over the past four decades, Iran devoted its best military minds, billions of dollars and sophisticated weapons to a grand project — countering U.S. and Israeli power in the Middle East through what it called the “axis of resistance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Onstad
title: A New Movie Dares to Suggest that Motherhood Might Be (Gasp) Fun
description: “Nightbitch” seems like a horror film about the transformations demanded by motherhood, but its underlying message is much more radical than that.
content: Motherhood has a branding problem. According to a recent Pew Research Center study, a growing share of adults under 50 say they probably won’t have children, and women are even less interested than men. There are plenty of practical reasons — the cost of living and concerns about the environment top the list — but the collective cultural drumbeat about just how much motherhood stinks is no doubt playing a part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel W. Drezner
title: The Evolution of Marco Rubio
description: Rubio, the choice for secretary of state, has evolved from a hawkish optimist to a more inward-looking, antiglobalist pessimist.
content: When the first round of Donald Trump’s cabinet selections was announced last month, I was in Germany, participating in a round-table conversation on the future of American foreign policy. As the only American involved, I received many befuddled questions from the German interlocutors. Most of the names prompted some degree of confusion or consternation except for one: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida for secretary of state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Entous
title: Biden and Family of Austin Tice, Journalist Long Missing in Syria, Believe He Is Alive
description: President Biden said on Sunday that U.S. officials believe they can bring Mr. Tice home, but that they do not know where he is.
content: President Biden and the family of Austin Tice, an American journalist who disappeared in Syria in 2012, said on Sunday that they believe that he is alive and could be returned to the United States after rebels groups toppled the government of President Bashar al-Assad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 547
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 9, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna R. Japaridze and Frankie Mills
title: The Streets of My Country Are Full of Fury
description: Georgia is lurching toward authoritarianism. This may be our last chance to pull it back.
content: Acts of disobedience are exploding in the streets of Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Raja Abdulrahim
title: Who Is the Leader of Syria’s Rebel Offensive?
description: Abu Mohammad al-Jolani spearheaded a lightning assault that led to the fall of President Bashar al-Assad.
content: After attracting little notice for years, Abu Mohammad al-Jolani spearheaded a stunning lightning offensive that led to the fall of the regime of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria after over 13 years of brutal civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea’s Ex-Defense Chief Is Detained Over Martial Law Episode
description: Prosecutors are investigating whether President Yoon Suk Yeol and his followers committed insurrection when they briefly put South Korea under martial law.
content: Kim Yong-hyun, the former defense minister of South Korea, was taken into custody early Sunday as prosecutors investigated his role in President Yoon Suk Yeol’s short-lived effort last week to impose martial law. That episode set off political upheaval in South Korea, including an opposition-led attempt to impeach the president and huge protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Marvin Laird, Musical Presence on and Off Broadway, Dies at 85
description: He conducted Broadway shows and worked with Bernadette Peters. But he was probably best known for writing the music for the darkly comic “Ruthless!”
content: Marvin Laird, a conductor for Broadway musicals and for performers like Bernadette Peters who also composed the music for “Ruthless!,” the campy, award-winning Off Broadway show about a girl who will do anything — including kill — to star in a school play, died on Dec. 2 in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 8, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 8, 2024.
content: An article on Dec. 1 about Demetrius Crichlow, who was named the head of New York City Transit last month, misspelled the surname of the chief executive of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. He is Janno Lieber, not Leiber. It also misstated the number of riders served by New York City’s subway and bus system. Is it six million, not four million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ephrat Livni
title: Israeli Ground Forces Cross into Syria, Officials Say
description: Israeli ground forces have overtly crossed into Syrian territory for the first time since the 1973 October War, passing the demilitarized border zone, two Israeli officials said.
content: Israeli ground forces advanced beyond the demilitarized zone on the Israel-Syria border over the weekend, marking their first overt entry into Syrian territory since the 1973 October War, according to two Israeli officials speaking anonymously to discuss sensitive developments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: The Assad Family’s Legacy Is One of Savage Oppression
description: A dynasty bombed and detained thousands of opponents, building fearsome internal security agencies to quash unrest.
content: Over decades, ghastly, chilling images from Syria have cemented the Assad family’s legacy of savagely oppressing the country’s population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Foley
title: 8 Great Thrillers About Bad Marriages
description: Lucy Foley, the author of “The Guest List,” recommends books about the most intimate of dramas, including twisty mysteries and all-time favorites like “Rebecca” and “Gone Girl.”
content: What is it about marriages that makes them enduringly fertile material for the thriller treatment? Is it that we’re all incurably curious about the lives of others? Is it the schadenfreude of learning that an outwardly perfect union is anything but? Perhaps it’s the fascinating, unnerving suggestion that there may be secrets — terrible, life-upending secrets — even within the sanctuary of a person’s home and at the heart of this most intimate of relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was So Absorbed in My Notes That I Had Forgotten to Have Lunch’
description: A forbidden snack while studying, exercise to start the day and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lizzy  Goodman
title: Nick Cave Will Take a Selfie With You, if You Insist
description: Back out on the road, and after working through his extreme grief, the longtime rocker is connecting with more fans than ever.
content: On a bright and chilly fall afternoon in Dublin, the Australian musician Nick Cave strode down a wide street across from St. Stephen’s Green on his way to a knitwear shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What’s Next for Syria After the Collapse of Assad’s Government?
description: Predicting Syria’s future is challenging, as the government’s sudden demise took many people who have watched the region for years by surprise.
content: The collapse of the government of President Bashar al-Assad has sparked jubilation inside Syria and beyond, but it has also plunged the country into deep uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Tennessee Trans Treatment Case Is About Age, Not Sex
description: The state’s ban on gender-affirming medical care for minors passes the constitutional test.
content: I cannot begin to imagine the pain of feeling that your body does not match your gender. I cannot imagine the pain of parenting a child in such distress. Americans should feel immense sympathy for individuals in those circumstances, and we should feel an urgent necessity to treat children’s pain in the safest and most effective way possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Steve Mensch, President of Tyler Perry Studios, Dies at 62
description: Mr. Mensch, a longtime supporter of the film industry in Georgia, died in a plane crash on Friday in Florida, according to officials.
content: Steve Mensch, a film executive in Georgia who pushed for state policies to support the industry and who was the president of Tyler Perry Studios, died in a plane crash in Florida on Friday. He was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Angela Alvarez, Great-Grandmother Who Won a Latin Grammy, Dies at 97
description: Her only album made her a media star after she had raised four children and worked as a house cleaner — proving, she said, that “it’s never too late.”
content: Angela Alvarez, a Cuban-born singer and songwriter who, at age 95, became the oldest performer to win the Latin Grammy Award for best new artist, died on Friday in Baton Rouge, La., where she had settled after immigrating to the United States in the early 1960s. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Bill Clinton on the Election, D.E.I. and One of His Regrets
description: The former president spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit.
content: A month after losing the presidential election, Democrats are still unpacking what went wrong. Speaking at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, former President Bill Clinton blamed a lack of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: As Syrian Rebels Take Charge, Freeing Prisoners of Assad Is a Priority
description: Many people want to determine the fates of loved ones who disappeared into a notorious military prison that was a symbol of human rights abuses under President Bashar al-Assad.
content: For many Syrians, the fall of President Bashar al-Assad provides an opportunity — at last — to try to discover the fates of loved ones who disappeared into a notorious military prison that has become a symbol of human rights abuses under his rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Nations and Leaders React to Toppling of Syria Regime
description: The U.N. special envoy called it a “watershed moment” on Sunday as world leaders reckoned with the news.
content: Global leaders reacted to the toppling of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria with cautious optimism and support for the Syrian people on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Judge Pauses Sexual Abuse Lawsuit Against Trump’s Education Secretary Pick
description: Linda McMahon is accused of failing to stop abuse in the 1980s within W.W.E., which she led at the time. The suit is on hold pending a ruling over a state law related to such cases.
content: A federal judge in Maryland has paused a lawsuit against Linda McMahon, the former World Wrestling Entertainment executive whom President-elect Trump chose for education secretary, while another court weighs a recent state law involving such cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Israel Enters Demilitarized Buffer Zone in the Golan Heights
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, said he had ordered troops to “take over” the zone between his country and Syria.
content: Israel said Sunday that it had entered a demilitarized buffer zone in the Golan Heights, abutting Syrian-held territory, amid a lightning fast rebel offensive that swept across Syria and drove President Bashar al-Assad from power.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: At Stake in Syria Fight: Domination of Mideast
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 8, 2024.
content: “Syria is the barometer for how power dynamics in the region are changing. It is in for a period of chaos in a region that is already on fire.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: With Assad Gone, a Brutal Dictatorship Ends. But the New Risks Are Huge.
description: The overthrow of the Assad government could mean Russia’s bases in Syria are closed and Iran’s pathway to Hezbollah is cut off. Now Iran, newly vulnerable, will have to decide between negotiation and the bomb.
content: For years, the American strategic map of the Middle East was dominated by Iran at the center of power of a “Shia crescent,” with Syria as the funnel for the Iranian arms used by terrorism groups to attack Israel, and as the home to Russia’s naval and air presence in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Jin Yu Young
title: After Failed Martial Law, South Koreans Ask: Who’s in Charge?
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s ill-fated bid to impose martial law has created a power vacuum in his governing camp, pushing the country deeper into what analysts call a constitutional crisis.
content: South Korea’s government was paralyzed Sunday, mired in a new constitutional crisis after President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea clung to his office, but his own party’s leader suggested that he had already been ousted from power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Syria’s Army Was Hollowing Out Long Before Rebels’ Advance
description: While multiple factors contributed to the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, corrosion inside his own military did not help, analysts say.
content: For years, Syrian soldiers have been complaining on Facebook about their bosses. Commanders who took bribes in exchange for leave. Leaders who ordered soldiers to loot. Officers who stole their troops’ food or got drunk on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Chiung Yao, Influential Taiwanese Romance Novelist, Dies at 86
description: One of the most successful writers in the Chinese-speaking world, she filled her plots with twists and turns, but love always transcended all.
content: Chiung Yao, a romance writer who published some of the best-selling novels in the Chinese-speaking world and helped shape the idea of romantic love there for generations, died on Wednesday at her home in New Taipei City, Taiwan. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Did Trump Drain Democrats’ Energy? These Races Will Be the First Test.
description: As Democrats try to fire up their fatigued base, two contests for the Virginia legislature will serve as the first measure of partisan enthusiasm since Donald J. Trump’s victory.
content: Even as the exhausted nation recovers from its two-year presidential campaign, candidates in a pocket of Northern Virginia are gearing up for a pair of special elections that may serve as barometers of partisan enthusiasm in the Trump 2.0 era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Humdrum Routines
description: Elliot Caroll makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: He Was Shot in the Face. Now Ukraine Wants to Draft Him.
description: After being left for dead by Russian soldiers, Mykola Kulichenko doesn’t think he should be forced to serve. His experience highlights the vagaries of Ukraine’s aggressive mobilization.
content: Early in Russia’s war against Ukraine, Mykola Kulichenko endured an ordeal. He was abducted as a civilian, survived a Russian execution attempt by a stroke of luck and then climbed out of his own grave by pushing through the dirt heaped above him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: The Best Poetry Books of 2024
description: Here are the year’s most notable collections of verse as chosen by our poetry columnist.
content: A friend asked me recently what poetry is for. A somewhat difficult question! Another day, I may have answered differently, but on that occasion, I surprised myself by using the word religion. I was thinking of structure and practice — of dailiness and weekliness, of ritual, tradition, the way that returning again and again to foundational texts or the writing desk makes a certain order of experience more possible. The ritual, importantly, removes the burden of decision for some length of time as to where you’ll put your body, what you’ll do with it. This frees up room in the mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: At Daniel Penny’s Trial, the Moment May Matter as Much as the Evidence
description: Jordan Neely’s death on the subway would once have prompted persistent protests. But when it comes to the perception of threat, context is everything.
content: In some ways it is easy to see how the events of May 1, 2023, could be framed to support a narrative of a city lost in fear, exhausted by a sense of chaos. That afternoon, Daniel Penny left City Tech in Downtown Brooklyn, where he was studying architecture, and headed into Manhattan via the F train to the Flatiron branch of Life Time, the elite gym and wellness merchant. A few stops in, at Second Avenue, an unhinged Jordan Neely got on and threw his jacket to the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: ‘Wizard of Oz’ Ruby Slippers Sell at Auction for a Record $28 Million
description: The slippers, worn by Judy Garland in “The Wizard of Oz,” were stolen from the museum that bears her name in 2005 before investigators recovered them in 2018.
content: The ruby slippers that Judy Garland wore as Dorothy in the 1939 production of “The Wizard of Oz” were sold for a record-breaking $28 million on Saturday during a live auction in Dallas in the latest turn for one of the most recognizable and storied artifacts in film history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Signals an Aggressive Opening, Threatening ‘Jail’ for Cheney and Others
description: In his first sit-down broadcast network interview since winning re-election, President-elect Donald J. Trump vowed to pardon Capitol attackers and to try to end automatic citizenship for children of immigrants.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump outlined an aggressive plan for opening his second term in an interview that aired on Sunday, vowing to move immediately to crack down on immigration and pardon his most violent supporters while threatening to lock up political foes like Liz Cheney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Winners and Losers Following the Fall of al-Assad
description: Two cheers for the end of the regime, but be wary of what happens next.
content: The stunning collapse of the brutal Assad regime in Syria, a family business since the 1970s, is a geopolitical earthquake creating winners and losers around the world. First, the losers:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: A Mural, and the Heroic Efforts to Save It
description: When Pfizer moved to a new building in Manhattan last year, it left behind artwork that had hung in its lobby for 63 years. Not everyone was pleased.
content: For 63 years, a modernist sculptural mural in the lobby of Pfizer’s world headquarters on East 42nd Street in Manhattan celebrated a millennia-long parade of medical pioneers like Hippocrates and Louis Pasteur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: The Campaign by Syrian Rebels to Topple Assad Was Swift
description: President Bashar al-Assad had kept opposition forces at bay for a decade with help from Russia and Iran. But rebels struck at a moment of weakness for those countries.
content: The government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, which had kept rebel forces at bay for more than a decade with Iranian and Russian military support, collapsed with astonishing speed on Sunday morning after an advance by opposition forces on the capital, Damascus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: How Will Donald Trump’s Comeback Look on the Wall?
description: Portraits of the presidents hang outside the boardroom at The New York Times Building.
content: Outside the boardroom at The New York Times’s headquarters is a portrait gallery with every United States president since Theodore Roosevelt. Each picture is autographed or personalized in some way. The 45th president signed his photo to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., who was then the publisher: “Arthur — Great being with you — MAGA!” The 46th president signed his portrait: “NYT — A free press is the rock upon which democracy is built. Keep the faith!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,269
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 9, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Space Age Blues and the ‘Dancing Spirit’ of Judith Jamison
description: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater returns for its annual December season with an enigmatic premiere by Jamar Roberts and the revival of “Grace.”
content: When the curtain rises on “Al-Andalus Blues,” Jamar Roberts’s new work for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, it does so deliberately and unwaveringly, as if building drama before a big reveal. In this mysterious tableau, a group is planted on and around a glowing rock formation. (It looked like a lumpy mattress.) One figure draws the eye: Hannah Alissa Richardson, a dancer and a warrior rolled into one. Her arms serpentine around her. She looks like a flame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cacio e Pepe, Then Cacio e Pepe Again
description: This classic Roman pasta dish is a great thing to cook often, so the technique enters your muscle memory.
content: Good morning. You could spend a lifetime perfecting cacio e pepe, the classic Roman pasta dish of cheese and black pepper mixed with spaghetti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Trump Suggests Kennedy Will Examine Debunked Link Between Vaccines and Autism
description: The president-elect has promoted the theory for more than a decade and said on Sunday that he was “open to anything” to address a nationwide rise in autism.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump, who has promoted the debunked theory that vaccines cause autism for more than a decade, suggested on Sunday that he would have his choice for health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., look into the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jo Becker and Adam Rasgon
title: Records Seized by Israel Show Hamas Presence in U.N. Schools
description: While Israel asserts that the United Nations has tried to minimize the problem, the global organization says Israeli officials are waging an unfair campaign to discredit it.
content: To his students, Ahmad al-Khatib was a deputy principal at an elementary school in Gaza run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees. To Hamas’s military wing, documents say, he was something else entirely: an infantryman operating out of the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan DiTrolio
title: The Glorious, Behind-the-Scenes Mess That Is Cookie Week
description: A weeklong celebration of cookies takes months of planning and baking, not to mention various photo and video shoots.
content: During Cookie Week, New York Times Cooking unveils seven new cookie recipes to sweeten the holiday season. This year’s roundup includes matcha-black sesame shortbreads, holiday rocky road and even boozy almond bites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cai Guo-Qiang
title: Art and A.I.: Parallel Worlds, Bound Together
description: Artificial intelligence, though shrouded in risk, promises a revolution in how we see the world.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ségolène Le Stradic, Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
title: Notre-Dame Holds First Public Mass in Years: ‘Fire Has Not Conquered Stone’
description: Sunday was the first opportunity for worshipers to return to the cathedral, beloved by the faithful and secular alike, since the 2019 fire that devastated it.
content: Many Parisians can tell you exactly what they were doing when they heard that Notre-Dame was burning five years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Will We Ever Elect a Woman as President?
description: Readers react to a column by Gail Collins. Also: Advice for immigrants; presidential immunity; words of the year.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Trump Says He Does Not Have Plans to Replace Fed Chair
description: Donald J. Trump, the president-elect, said he doesn’t “see it” when asked if he would try to oust the head of America’s central bank.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump said he has no plans to fire the chair of the Federal Reserve, Jerome H. Powell, addressing an uncertainty that has been hanging over the politically independent central bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: Must I Share My Story?
description: A reader asks whether she needs to let her new colleagues, most of whom work remotely, know that she is undergoing chemotherapy treatments.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Muhammad Haj Kadour
title: As Syrian Government Loses Control, the Skies Above Go Quiet
description: For years, people lived in terror of airstrikes by Syrian and Russian planes that helped keep the country’s authoritarian leader in power.
content: For more than a decade of civil war, Syrians in rebel-held areas craned their necks to look at the sky — listening and fearing the sounds of an airplane engine or the whirring blades of a helicopter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Monday Briefing: Al-Assad Flees Syria as Rebels Claim Power
description: Plus, Notre-Dame reopens.
content: President Bashar al-Assad has resigned and fled Syria for Russia, according to Russian state news media outlets, a stunning fall for a longtime dictator who had kept rebel forces at bay for years with the help of Moscow and Tehran. Follow for live updates here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giles Harvey
title: What Alice Munro Knew
description: The Nobel-winning author’s husband was a pedophile who targeted her daughter and other children. Why did she stay silent?
content: “My life has gone rosy, again,” Alice Munro told a friend in a buoyant letter of March 1975. For Munro, who was then emerging as one of her generation’s leading writers, the previous few years were blighted by heartbreak and upheaval: a painful separation from her husband of two decades; a retreat from British Columbia back to her native Ontario; a series of brief but bruising love affairs, in which, it seems, Munro could never quite make out the writing on the wall. “This time it’s real,” she wrote, speaking of a new romantic partner, the emphasis acknowledging that her friend had heard these words before. “He’s 50, free, a good man if I ever saw one, tough and gentle like in the old tire ads, and this is the big thing — grown-up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Trump on ‘Meet the Press’: Tariffs, Immigration and More
description: The president-elect repeated several false and inaccurate claims on a range of topics that were staples of his 2024 campaign.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump, in his first sit-down broadcast interview since his re-election last month, repeated several false and inaccurate claims on a range of topics that were staples of his 2024 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
title: Syrians in Lebanon Start to Head Home, With Both Joy and Worry
description: Thousands who fled during the country’s civil war celebrated the toppling of the Assad government — and their long-awaited return home — at the Syria-Lebanon border crossing.
content: They poured by the thousands into the street outside Lebanon’s main border crossing with Syria, celebrating the toppling of the Assad regime — and their long-awaited return home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: For 8 Months, Traffic Enforcement on New Jersey’s Highways Plummeted
description: After a report found racial bias in traffic enforcement, state troopers were warned by a union leader that “every stop” would be scrutinized. They started making fewer.
content: In July 2023, New Jersey state troopers who patrol the state’s busiest highways and remote rural roads suddenly began writing far fewer traffic enforcement tickets. The next month, citations for speeding, drunken driving, cellphone use and other violations plummeted by 81 percent across the state compared with the year before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: How a Never-Ending Home Renovation Project Is Fighting Climate Change
description: Forrest Meggers, a professor at Princeton University, has turned his home into a live-in laboratory that pushes the boundaries of sustainability.
content: Two years ago, on a tree-lined street in Princeton, N.J., a truck-mounted drill arrived at a modest two-story home. Its goal? To dig a 500-foot hole in the front yard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
title: Stunned Iranian Officials Try to Distance Their Country From Assad
description: A reckoning emerged in Iran on Sunday as officials and commentators swiftly moved to distance the government from a tyrant it had supported.
content: Iranians watched in astonishment over the weekend as the reign of their nation’s longtime political and military ally, Bashar al-Assad, came to a crashing end. By Sunday, the reckoning had arrived as officials and pundits recognized that Iran was taken by surprise, and they hurried to distance Iran from a tyrant the country had supported in maintaining power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Bogged Down in Ukraine, Russia Pays a Price in Syria
description: With the fall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, Vladimir V. Putin has suffered one of the biggest geopolitical setbacks of his quarter-century in power.
content: Lines of Russian troops in desert khaki greeted President Vladimir V. Putin in Syria in 2017. Declaring that Moscow had accomplished its mission in Syria’s civil war, Mr. Putin pledged that Russia was there to stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Top-Gun Navy Pilots Fly at the Extremes. Their Brains May Suffer.
description: A confidential Navy program is studying whether intense fighter jet operations can cause devastating brain injuries in flight crews.
content: To produce the best of the best, the Navy’s elite TOPGUN flying school puts fighter pilots through a crucible of intense, aerial dogfighting maneuvers under crushing G forces. But behind the high-speed Hollywood heroics that the school is famous for, the Navy has grown concerned that the extreme flying may also be producing something else: brain injuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik and Axel Boada
title: Syrians Celebrate as Rebels Force Bashar al-Assad Out of Power
description: Gunfire and cheering erupted across Syria after rebels took control of Damascus, the capital, and ended President Bashar al-Assad’s authoritarian regime.
content: Gunfire and cheering erupted across Syria after rebels took control of Damascus, the capital, and ended President Bashar al-Assad’s authoritarian regime.
source.name: The New York Times
